articles.headline: Top Two Officers on Navy Ship in Deadly Collision Off Japan Are Relieved of Duties
articles.snippet: The ship, the destroyer Fitzgerald, collided with a cargo freighter in the middle of the night, killing seven sailors.
articles.abstract: The ship, the destroyer Fitzgerald, collided with a cargo freighter in the middle of the night, killing seven sailors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two top officers aboard a destroyer during a deadly collision off the coast of Japan in June were relieved of their duties on Friday, the Navy’s Seventh Fleet said. A number of other sailors were punished for their roles in the crash.

articles.headline: Where Is the Line? Charlottesville Forces Media and Tech Companies to Decide
articles.snippet: In the wake of a tragedy, the media universe is grappling with an issue it has avoided for years.
articles.abstract: In the wake of a tragedy, the media universe is grappling with an issue it has avoided for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took the death of a young woman at the hands of one of the neo-Nazis she was protesting to force the ever-expanding media universe to face a question it has been evading for years: Where’s the line?

articles.headline: For Uber, a Quiet Investor Becomes a Sudden Thorn
articles.snippet: Benchmark, a venerable Silicon Valley start-up investor, is caught in a bitter public brawl with Uber’s co-founder, Travis Kalanick. It’s an unusual position for the firm.
articles.abstract: Benchmark, a venerable Silicon Valley start-up investor, is caught in a bitter public brawl with Uber’s co-founder, Travis Kalanick. It’s an unusual position for the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the past week, Uber’s board members have been embroiled in conversations over a thorny question: what to do about Benchmark, the venture capital firm that is one of the ride-hailing company’s largest shareholders.

articles.headline: The Case Some Executives Made for Sticking With Trump
articles.snippet: As the president’s advisory councils were disbanding, a few corporate chieftains made a case in terms of business self-interest, patriotism and pragmatism.
articles.abstract: As the president’s advisory councils were disbanding, a few corporate chieftains made a case in terms of business self-interest, patriotism and pragmatism.
articles.lead_paragraph: As corporate chieftains on a White House advisory panel debated on Wednesday on whether to disband, a few spoke up in favor of sticking with President Trump.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Shell of Old G.M. Surfaces in Court Fight Over Ignition Flaw
articles.snippet: Plaintiffs’ lawyers thought they had a deal with a trust for the prebankruptcy General Motors to benefit their clients. Then the new G.M. intervened.
articles.abstract: Plaintiffs’ lawyers thought they had a deal with a trust for the prebankruptcy General Motors to benefit their clients. Then the new G.M. intervened.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For eight years, the shell of prebankruptcy General Motors has lingered on in the form of “old G.M.” — first as a corporate entity and now as an obscure trust designed to settle debts and claims left over from the company’s huge financial collapse.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: ‘Antifa’ Grows as Left-Wing Faction Set to, Literally, Fight the Far Right
articles.snippet: Recent events in Charlottesville, Va., where white nationalists clashed with counterprotesters, have brought new attention to a coalition of radicals unafraid to scuffle with right-wing extremists.
articles.abstract: Recent events in Charlottesville, Va., where white nationalists clashed with counterprotesters, have brought new attention to a coalition of radicals unafraid to scuffle with right-wing extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Last weekend, when a 27-year-old bike messenger showed up at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Va., he came ready for battle. He joined a human chain that stretched in front of Emancipation Park and linked his arms with others, blocking waves of white supremacists — some of them in full Nazi regalia — from entering.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Alan Feuer and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Police See Wider Plot in Spain and Say Carnage Could Have Been Worse
articles.snippet: They now believe that a tiny Mediterranean town may have been the incubator for a conspiracy far more ambitious than the attacks in Catalonia.
articles.abstract: They now believe that a tiny Mediterranean town may have been the incubator for a conspiracy far more ambitious than the attacks in Catalonia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — When an earthshaking explosion on Wednesday blew apart a house outside Alcanar, a town surrounded by olive groves and holiday homes overlooking the Mediterranean, the police first blamed it on a gas leak.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Patrick Kingsley and Palko Karasz

articles.headline: Trump Says More Jobs Will Help Race Relations. If Only It Were So Simple.
articles.snippet: Racial attitudes don’t jump around with the economy, and well-being is about more than jobs.
articles.abstract: Racial attitudes don’t jump around with the economy, and well-being is about more than jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has a simple answer for racial tension in the United States: jobs.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Borrower Got Unneeded Insurance, and Ruined Credit
articles.snippet: Allan Dunlap was among 800,000 Wells Fargo borrowers wrongly charged for auto coverage. The bank admits errors, but he’s had to fight to be made whole.
articles.abstract: Allan Dunlap was among 800,000 Wells Fargo borrowers wrongly charged for auto coverage. The bank admits errors, but he’s had to fight to be made whole.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has promised to make amends to the customers it forced to buy car insurance that they didn’t need. Allan Dunlap, a former Wells Fargo borrower who spent months trying to get the bank to correct an insurance error that marred his credit report, says he’ll believe it when he sees it.

articles.headline: China Steps Up Warnings Over Debt-Fueled Overseas Acquisitions
articles.snippet: The announcement by China’s cabinet is the strongest signal yet that Beijing wants to rein in runaway debt that could pose a threat to its economy.
articles.abstract: The announcement by China’s cabinet is the strongest signal yet that Beijing wants to rein in runaway debt that could pose a threat to its economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China moved on Friday to curb investment overseas by its companies and conglomerates, issuing its strongest signal yet that it wants to rein in runaway debt that could pose a threat to the country’s slowing economy.

articles.headline: Infosys Chief Quits After Battle With Founders
articles.snippet: Vishal Sikka’s departure from the Indian technology giant comes just months after a similar struggle at the top of the Tata Group, a powerful conglomerate.
articles.abstract: Vishal Sikka’s departure from the Indian technology giant comes just months after a similar struggle at the top of the Tata Group, a powerful conglomerate.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India Inc. suffered a new blow on Friday when the chief executive of one of the country’s leading technology outsourcing companies suddenly resigned, a surprise move he attributed to “a continuous drumbeat of distractions and negativity.”
